intro: Myagrum amphibium, commonly known as the swamp hibiscus, is a flowering plant native to tropical and subtropical regions. It is characterized by its broad, waxy leaves and showy, five-petaled flowers that typically range in color from white to pink. The plant thrives in wetland environments, often found in marshes, swamps, and along the edges of ponds. Its botanical structure includes a woody stem and fibrous roots adapted to waterlogged soils. Myagrum amphibium plays an important ecological role by providing habitat and food for various aquatic and terrestrial organisms.
